title: Rusty, our 1962 11 window bus, resto now in year two…...

posts.content:
Looks awesome mate, very very impressed!!! Loads done and to a fantastic quality!

Love the ingenious Calpol Sealer, did you taste it to see if it was still sweet?

wejjy wrote:
Looks awesome mate, very very impressed!!! Loads done and to a fantastic quality!

Love the ingenious Calpol Sealer, did you taste it to see if it was still sweet?


Funnily enough I did end up with some on my lips, but dunno how it got there. Just hope the boys don't get a high temperature tonight, at least not 'til it's dried

Worked well though
Mmm Calpol. Happy memories from childhood.
My you lot have good memories...
Just sat down with my evening cuppa for a read mate and its all blank!! Don't tell me you've been too busy again!! Gutted!
Guilty as charged

type21f wrote:
...as said the resto police will not get you...that ****p is a bugger for checking up to see what you have done...He'll laugh if he read's my thread..
He calls me "The Riddler" cos he always needs a translation when I send him mails...
He does not spake G spake..

see what he sayzzzzzzzzzzz




LOL ..... The Ridder sticks again



All I'm saying is bloody well done its really looking good ..and to spend the time on getting the sealer to look good is so important as it will only bug you if you miss a bit ....its really looking good now ..... A real pro job


Not to long now and we'll be sipping on a bud at VF talking resto and if sheilas in ear shot " how cheep it is to rest a bus these days "


Laters

M

Evening all

No time again today but did give Dad a hand with the Vespa strip down for an hour or so





Rusty got post today



I now have enough pop out catches to make up a reasonable set of six. Not pristine but acceptable until more come along. Thanks to Rick T for the parcel today

My problem is that all the bottom knobs have been lost from my ones and £20 seems a bit steep from AHS etc. considering I only need the ivory knobs that unscrew. I'm looking for alternatives. Any ideas anyone or should I play up and look big? I was thinking chrome dome nuts. Ideas anyone??

That's all for today. Beavers and a pint looms

Cheers,

Steve

Evening all

Just a quickie tonight. Enthusiasm lacking I finally decided that I would seam seal the bottom of the spare wheel well. I've been stressing about how I get it looking perfect and it doesn't really matter 'cos no one will see it so I put in the "first pass"



then fussed and finessed and once that's gone off, I'll do a final coat and it will be………….more than acceptable



Once I'd done that, I was stymied as I had to wait for the sealer to cure, so back onto the cab door repair, which always seems to be there I'd fabbed the repair piece a while ago, and drilled couple of holes in it for plugging. The Fertan had, by now, worked its magic



I was on a bit of a tight schedule as I'd agreed to play squash with someone, but I didn't want to rush things ( that's why it will take three years to do Rusty whereas everyone else seems to do it in half the time). I gradually tacked it in whilst making sure I kept the edges flush.



I have to say that I still enjoy welding but sometime think I should stick to mending wheel barrows and suchlike but luckily I have a grinder

I left it there and it's not looking too bad

I've not had any news on my engine, but I'm taking my AT gearbox up to Bears in a few weeks to get that reworked and checked out. I'm having the final drive changed to a 0.89 instead of the stock 0.93……apparently

Still, no turning back now. Rusty must be finished for Viccy Farm

That's all folks

Cheers

Steve

You shouldn't be so picky about your work dude, its awesome! Youve got an eye for detail and its a blessing and a curse, it looks great afterwards but drives you nuts during! Keep going mate and dont lose enthusiasm now, seeing your progress keeps me going!!

Looking forward to hearing about your engine dude, and hope it all goes smoothly with Bears.

Will check back tomorrow for your next update pal!

wejjy wrote:
You shouldn't be so picky about your work dude, its awesome! Youve got an eye for detail and its a blessing and a curse, it looks great afterwards but drives you nuts during! Keep going mate and dont lose enthusiasm now, seeing your progress keeps me going!!

Looking forward to hearing about your engine dude, and hope it all goes smoothly with Bears.

Will check back tomorrow for your next update pal!




Love the way you and Wejjy feed of each other threads thus keeping you focused and 100% committed

Its what these threads are all about for me and also along the way you learn stuff to and pick up methods that otherwise you would not have tried


So well done guys and keep on pushing .... Rest police is near too faraway


Mark

Evening all

Not much doing I managed a couple of hours and got the final lot of seam sealer in the wheel well, but it's not photogenic

I carried on with the cab door repair and its not too bad



I don't know how to finish it off though. There will invariably be one or two tiny pin holes. I can't seam seal in the back seams and moisture will get in there from rain running in off the windows. Do I fill what I can, seam sealer what I can from the front ????? It will be waxoyled (or equivalent). What"s the proper procedure when treating these old doors? Answers asap please people as the weekend looms.

We're getting our act together for Viccy Farm. This turned up today



Well…….. I owe one or two folks a beer. My wife's an Aussie . We can't have warm beer….that would be a no no. And for the record, Aussies don't drink Fosters The picture on the box shows it full of beer….. I bet it's not

Cheers

Steve

mmmmmm Beer

You can't go wrong with a elec fridge buddy I have a elec fridge but my Claire rams it full of food


So I treated myself to an IGLOO 5 DAY COOLER BOX ... ya fill it full of ice and it stays proper cold for 5 days .... and I can vouch that it works sweet still have ice in water after day 5 and beers were LUSH cold

Gerrys Trailer is for the beers


Door repair looks sweet well done

Mark

I wouldn't stress about about the door repairs - they look perfect.
By the time its been primed with hi-build, and then painted as well - I'd be very surprised if there are any holes left in it - plus you're going to waxoyl (or similar) the inside cavity which will fill any imperfections, plus you've got two whacking great drain holes anyway - a few pinpricks won't make any difference....
But I'm confident you won't have any.
Looking good!

ted698 wrote:
I wouldn't stress about about the door repairs - they look perfect.
By the time its been primed with hi-build, and then painted as well - I'd be very surprised if there are any holes left in it - plus you're going to waxoyl (or similar) the inside cavity which will fill any imperfections, plus you've got two whacking great drain holes anyway - a few pinpricks won't make any difference....
But I'm confident you won't have any.
Looking good!


Thanks Ted, we think the same There will be a few pinpricks but I do my best. It's the seams I can't do much about, but neither did VW originally as far as I can see. As you say, once hi build and waxoyl has gone on, the holes will be filled. Thanks for your reply

Steve
